text:
head coverings worn by muslim women
burka: full body, covers entire face, a mesh screen covers the eyes
niqab: veil for the face, eyes remain visible
hijab: square scarf covers head and neck
chador: full-body cloak
shayla: long scarf, wrapped around the head
al-amira: two-piece headscarf
khimar: cape-like covering hair, neck and shoulders
caption: The image is a visual guide illustrating various head coverings worn by Muslim women, each accompanied by a brief description. It features six different types of coverings: the Burka, which is a full-body covering with a mesh screen over the eyes; the Niqab, which covers the face except for the eyes; the Hijab, a square scarf that covers the head and neck; the Chador, a full-body cloak; the Shayla, a long scarf wrapped around the head; the Al-Amira, a two-piece headscarf; and the Khimar, a cape-like covering that drapes over the head, neck, and shoulders. Each type of covering is depicted with an image of a woman wearing it, providing a clear visual representation of how each is worn.
